Dialogue: DON'T... Don't muck me about. You've had plenty of time to fix him up, and he's leaving with me, NOW. Do you understand me? Now, Mr. Treves. We had a bargain!

Dialogue: You misunderstood. This man suffered a severe fall, if you take my meaning. He's my patient now and I must do what...

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Pull the other one, why don't you! We made a deal!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I know what you've done to him and he's never going back to that.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: He's a freak! That's how they live. We're partners, him and I, business partners. You're willfully deprivin' me of my livlihood!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: All you do is profit from another man's misery!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: You think you're better 'n me? YOU wanted the freak to show all your doctor chums and make a name for yourself, you guv. So I gave him to you. On trust, in the name of science! And now I want him back.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: You don't own this man!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: I want him back!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: So you can beat him? So you can starve him? A dog in the street would fare better with you!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: I've got my rights, damn you, and I'm going to the authorities!

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: By all means do so. In fact, I'll fetch them myself. I'm quite sure they'd be very interested in your story, as well as ours.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Now I think we really do understand one another.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Right... Right.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Singularly unpleasant chap... uh... I don't suppose there would be any harm in my meeting your... patient, Mr. Treves.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Thank you very much Sir. Shall we say in a few days then?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Shall we say two o'clock tomorrow afternoon?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Wh... whatever is most convenient for you, sir.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Two o'clock then... you know Treves... It seems this acquaintance of yours has become rather more than just an acquaintance.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: ...Yes, Sir.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Two o'clock?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Elephant Man? I don't want to meet an Elephant Man.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Freddie?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Freddie?... Freddie, don't look so discouraged.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I shouldn't be. We made great progress today. I taught him to repeat a few basic phrases. He did rather well, too, but I had to lead him every step of the way. Though frankly, at times I was unsure of who was leading whom.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Well, I wasn't sure whether he was parroting me because that's all he was capable of, or whether he sensed that that's all I wanted to hear, and he was trying to please me.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: But I thought you said that he was rather... simple?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: He is. I mean, I've always thought he was. I think he must be. Is he simple? Or is that just something I've wished upon him to make things simpler for myself?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Frederick, why are you so interested in this particular case?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I don't know. I can't explain it. If this is an intelligent man, trapped in the body of a monster, then I'm under a moral obligation to help free that mind, free that spirit as best I can, to help him live as full and content a life as possible. But! If he's an imbecile, who's body I can't treat and who's mind I can't touch, well, then my obligation is discharged. They can put him where they will; he won't be bothered, I won't be bothered, and everyone's conscience can remain free and untroubled. And that is my dilemma... what is in his mind?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Perhaps you're just polishing a stone, endowing this Elephant Man with qualities he doesn't possess?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: And what qualities are those? Intelligence or stupidity?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I'm sure I don't know, Freddie.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I'm sorry... I don't know either. I just don't know.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Well, these things take time.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I've only got until two o'clock tomorrow afternoon, when Carr Gomm meets him. Somehow, between now and then I've got to make John Merrick at least seem like an intelligent man... Why am I fooling myself? Nothing short of John delivering the Sermon on the Mount is going to sway Carr Gomm...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Righteousness...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Very good, very good. Now, when your visitor comes today I want you to say it exactly the way you said it just now. I will introduce him to you and you will say the words you've learned. If you have any trouble with any of the words, I'll help you. I'm sure you'll be just fine. If you do as well for him as you've done for me these last two days, then I'm sure our visitor will be very pleased. Now, let's go through the whole thing again, shall we? I will say "May I introduce you to Mr. Carr Gomm." And you will say...

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Hello, my name is John Merrick. I am very pleased to meet you!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: It's only a physical problem. He has trouble with certain sounds because of the constrictive deformity of the mouth. But he can talk, and has a great eagerness to make contact with people who will let him. So if you have any difficulty understanding what he is saying, just tell me and I'll make it clear.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Speaking is one thing, Treves, but can the man comprehend?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: ...As I said, it's only a physical problem... but I do feel that Mr. Merrick is very flattered that you're taking the time and trouble to meet him, and he's most anxious to make a good impression, so he might seem rather nervous.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: He needn't. I have no desire to cause him any discomfort. Did you make those inquiries we spoke about?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, I spoke to both the British Home and Royal Hospital for Incurables. I'm afraid that they weren't very encouraging, but they said they'd bring it up at their next committee meeting, so we should have their answers shortly.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Fine, fine. You know, your dedication to this patient is an inspiring thing, Treves. But you must remember that this is a hospital, and there are many patients here. Patients who can be made well, and you owe them your first consideration. Just don't become so obsessed, old man, that you begin to neglect them.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John, may I introduce you to Sir Carr Gomm.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Hello... my name is John Merrick. I am very pleased to meet you.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I'm very... pleased to meet you.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: How are you feeling today?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I feel much better. Thank you for asking. And you?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I'm feeling very fit, thank you. How is your bronchitis?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I feel much better. Thank you.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Are you comfortable here?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Everyone has been very kind. I am extremely grateful.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Mr. Merrick likes the food here. Don't you John?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh yes! It is much better than what I am used to.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Oh yes?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: And what was that, John?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Potatoes...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: ...Yes potatoes... but...

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: But the variety of food here is very pleasing... I commend you.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I understand that you were beaten?

Speaker: dierrick
Dialogue: Oh no, everyone has been very kind.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: No, I meant in your former situation.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I'm feeling much better now...

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Tell me, how do you like Mr. Treves? As a teacher?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: ...I... everyone has been very kind to me.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Of course. How long did you and Mr. Treves prepare for this interview?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: ...everyone has been very kind.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Yes, of course... Well, it's been a pleasure meeting you, Mr. Merrick. Good day.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Thank you, John. You did very well.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: It was a nice try, Treves, but the man is so obviously mouthing your words.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, I'm very sorry to have wasted your time, sir. I just felt that I had to do anything I could to protect him.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I'm sorry too. He simply doesn't belong here. He's be much happier somewhere else, where he could be constantly looked after. Believe me, Frederick, it's better that it worked out this way. Good day.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: What is it, Treves?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I didn't teach him that part!

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: My cup runneth over. Surely goodness and loving kindness shall follow me all the days of my life, and I shall dwell in the house of the Lord forever.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: How did you, know the rest? I never taught you the rest of it.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Tell me, John, how did you know the rest of the 23rd Psalm?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I... I used to read the Bible every day. I know it very well. The Bible, and the Book of Common Prayer. The 23rd Psalm is very beautiful.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I am very pleased to meet you.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I hope we can talk together again sometime. Good day.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I'll be right back.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I want to see you in my office as soon as you're through up here. We've a good deal to discuss.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Of course, sir. Thank you, thank you very much.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Treves. Well done.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Not me, sir. Mr. Merrick. He succeeded in spite of my shortsightedness.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Why did you let me go on like that, teaching you what you already knew? Why didn't you tell me you could read?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: You did not ask me.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I never thought to ask. How can you ever forgive me?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh, no do not say that. You have been so kind to me. I was afraid to say too much. People always want me to be quiet. You wanted me to speak, but I was afraid. Forgive me.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: We do have a lot to talk about, don't we?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Can you imagine what his life has been like?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, I think I can.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: No you can't. You can't begin to know, no one can.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: You are quite right, Treves, this is an exceptional case. And I quite agree that the committee should see Mr. Merrick.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I could easily arrange...

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: No, not that way. Broadneck and the others don't like to deal with patients directly. It makes them queasy... Do you have any photographs of Mr. Merrick?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Well, yes.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Excellent. We shall present them, along with the other particulars of the case to the committee. I want them to see, exactly, how horribly his body has been affected. You and I shall vouch for his inner qualities.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Do you think they'll go along with us?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Of course they will. They're reasonable men.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Read it.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Thou heardest my voice; hide not thine ear at my breathing, At my cry.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Credit where credit is due. You'll have the paper every morning at breakfast.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: I hear you have some trouble sleepin'...

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Head's too heavy, eh?

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: And I heard a nasty rumor about you; I heard you can talk but you can't, can you... can you... can you?...

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Noooo!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: No... No you can't! One word about me out of that stinking cakehole... Just ONE word, and you'll have no trouble at sleepin'... no trouble at all. You understand me? Do you!!

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yyyesss.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: There now, that's better, i'n' it?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: As far as I can see, the only obstacle might be Broadneck. He has enormous influence over the others, very old school, not an easy man to impress. In any case, if worse does come to worse, we still have the British and Royal Homes to fall back on, don't we.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Don't we?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: No, we don't. Their committees have informed me that they're unwilling to take Mr. Merrick, even if they were supplied with funds. They don't want him.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Well, it's up to us then, isn't it?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Don't worry Treves, we'll make them see it our way.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: They've eyes, haven't they?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Forgive the redundancy, gentlemen, but there is no other place for him. Both the Royal Hospital and the British Home have turned him down even if sufficient funds for his care were provided. The workhouse is certainly out of the question. The patient has an overwhelming fear of returning to the horrors of his past. His appearance is so disturbing that all shrink from him. He cannot, in justice to others, be put in the general ward of the workhouse. The police rightly prevent his being exhibited, and he is mobbed in the streets wherever he goes. What is to be done with him?

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: I, for one, am sick and tired of this competitive freak-hunting by these overly ambitious young doctors, trying to make names for themselves. To parade then about in front of the pathological society is one thing, but to waste this committee's valuable time with requests for shelter for these abominations of nature is quite another.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Gentlemen, John Merrick is not an animal, he is a man, fully aware of his condition. An intelligent, sensitive, literate man, with an intimate knowledge of the Bible. His horrible infirmities do not reduce him to anything less than what he is, a man; and it would be criminal if we of the London Hospital, his final refuge, the last place on earth where this man can find peace, were to cast him out.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Gentlemen, may I make a suggestion. There are two small rooms off Bedstead Square that are no longer in use and would be admirably suited to Mr. Merrick's needs. I also propose to write a letter to The Times, appealing to their readers for assistance. Knowing the generosity of the British public, I feel we would have little trouble in raising the funds for his maintenance. Indeed, this hospital's rules do preclude the admission of incurables, but if ever there was an exception to the rule, it is this patient. So therefore, I propose, if Mr. Treves is finished, that we put it to a vote. All those in favor of keeping Mr. Merrick here?

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: One moment,  and when you appeal for funds, I think you should appeal for a more appropriate place for him as well. I agree the British public is generous, and I'm sure that somewhere the creature will find a happy and permanent home, but not here.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I see. All, then, that move we keep Mr. Merrick here?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: All those opposed?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: Well then. In the meantime, of course, he needn't be turned out. He may stay in the rooms off Bedstead Square until such time as more suitable arrangements can be made, thus freeing the Isolation Ward for more deserving patients. Well then, Mr. Chairman, if there is nothing further to discuss, I move that we adjourn this meeting and all go bout our normal business.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I second the motion gentlemen. This meeting is adjourned.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: ...terrible though his appearance is, so terrible indeed that women and nervous persons fly in terror from the sight of him, and that he is debarred from seeking to earn his livelihood in any ordinary way, yet he is superior in intelligence, can read and write, is quiet, gentle, not to say even refined in his mind.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I'd very much like to meet that gentleman. He sounds almost Shakespearean.

Speaker: fox
Dialogue: Do continue reading, Mr. Stanley, please.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Excuse me gentlemen. I seem to have lost my appetite. Good evening.

Speaker: fox
Dialogue: Well, no one did ask you Atkins. Frederick Treves is not only the most skillful surgical operator here, he's also a humanitarian of the highest order. You sound like a pack of whining school boys with your petty jealousies.

Speaker: fox
Dialogue: Oh belt up!

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: "A silent shaft of stone on a deserted promontory, the lonely Eddystone is a beacon of aid and comfort to mariners of all nations."

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Good evening. How are you feeling?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Good evening. Very well, thank you. And you?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Very well, thank you. I have something for you, John. I'm sure you'll enjoy it, it's very popular.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Thank you... so much... oh it's beautiful!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I came to tell you that I'll be here early tomorrow morning. We're moving you to your permanent home. I'm sure you'll be very happy there, John. So get a good night's rest, there'll be new people to meet tomorrow. Good night.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Here... listen to this. This is a letter to THE London Times from the guvnor of the hospital.  There is now in a little room off one of our attic wards a man named John Merrick, so dreadful a sight that he is unable even to come out by daylight to the garden. He has been called The Elephant Man on account of his terrible deformity...

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: ...His appearance is so terrible that woman and nervous persons fly in terror at the sight of him.  ...and guess who can get you tickets to see him? Your own Sunny Jim!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Keep your shirts on.  ...When the time is right. Right now he's in the attic but tomorrow they're movin' him into Bedstead Square, right into my lap... then... for the right price you'll see something you'll never see again in your life.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Workhouse!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: This is your new home, John.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: This... is my new home?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: The hospital?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Of course! What did you think?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: How long will I stay here?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I promise you. You will never see the inside of that horrible place again. You will never, ever go back to the workhouse... or that man. It's a splendid room, don't you think?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: When I'm next moved may I go to a lighthouse?... or to a blind-asylum?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Has the response picked up?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Frankly, Treves, it's not what I'd expected. A few small cheques. Well- wishers. Don't worry, these things undoubtedly take time.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: But he's so afraid he's going to be carted off. I've promised him that won't happen.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Well... I'll let you know if there's something in the afternoon post.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Please do.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Well, I think I can safely hand the duties over to you girls now. Mr. Merrick will require a bath every day... that way he won't pong quite so much. Nora, you can instruct Kathleen on the finer points of Mr. Merrick's bath. You'll be on your own tomorrow.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Don't look so glum girls. Such enthusiastic volunteers should be more cheerful.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Oh, and girls, under no circumstances are there to be any mirrors brought into this room.

Speaker: kathleen
Dialogue: He's... so ugly!

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: Ugly or not, you're going to help me.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: Feeling better now, Mr. Merrick?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: You look very nice in your new clothes.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Thank you very much.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: Well, if there is nothing more, I suppose we'll be leaving you now.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: No, nothing.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: You look splendid, John.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Thank you very much.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: When one is invited to tea, one must look one's best.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Come and meet our quest, my love.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John Merrick, I'd like you to meet my wife, Anne Treves.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I'm very pleased to meet you, Mr. Merrick.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I'm very...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John... what's the matter? John... why are you upset?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I'm not used to such kindness. From a beautiful woman.

Speaker: annne
Dialogue: Would you like a nice cup of tea, Mr. Merrick?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yes... thank you.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, a cup of tea would go nicely.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John... would you like to see the rest of the house?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Come with me, John. I'll show it to you.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Mr. Merrick, sugar?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yes please, two.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: One or two?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Two, please.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John loves the house.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh yes. You have so many nice things, and so much room.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, we do have a lot of room. But you should see the place on weekends, when I see patients here. Sometimes there are so many, we have to set them down wherever we can. In fact, Mrs. Treves sometimes says that the only room she can call her own is the bedroom.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Well, it's a lovely bedroom. What do you call that thing above the bed?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: That's a canopy, John.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Ohhh...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: How is your tea, John?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: It's very good. I'm enjoying my visit with you very much. It's so very kind of you to have me as a guest in your home. I'm sorry I made a spectacle of myself.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Not at all, John.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I love the way you've arranged your pictures on the mantlepiece. Is that the way it's done in most houses?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Oh yes.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Who are they of?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Oh, our relatives... the children.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: The children! May I see?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: The Children. Where are your children

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Oh, they're gone for the day... with friends.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Friends. Ah yes, friends! How nice.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: And here is one of Frederick's mother.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: How lovely.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: And here are my mother and father.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: They have noble faces.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I've always thought that myself.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Would you... would you like to see my mother?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Your mother?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh... why Mr. Merrick she's beautiful.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: She has the face of an angel... She was an angel. She was so kind... so kind to me. It's not her fault, for in the fourth month of her maternal condition she was knocked down by an elephant. I'm sure I must have been a great disappointment to her.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. No. No son as loving as you are could ever be a disappointment.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: If only I could find her. If only she could see me now, here, with such lovely kind friends. You, Mrs. Treves, and you, Mr. Treves. Then maybe she would love me as I am. I've tried to hard to be good.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Please... please...

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: Good morning, Mr. Merrick.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: What is this that you're doing?

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: What? Oh! I see! It's St. Phillips. Oh, of course. Why... why that's very good, I mean you've gotten the windows and arches just right.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: But it's so good, I mean... it's so very good.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Thank you... very much.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: Where did you get this box?

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: The hallway? Oh, the wastecan!

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I meant no harm, it was the only place where I could find cardboard. I thought it has been thrown away.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: It's alright, it was thrown away. No one wants it. It's just that it's a little dirty, that's all.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: The main spire.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: The... oh, the spire! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... Mr. Merrick, where did you learn to do this?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: ...I learned a long time ago.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: Oh, but how will you finish it? You haven't any more cardboard.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I'll have to find some more.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: Yes... well, good day, Mr. Merrick.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Good morning, John.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John, there's someone here who would like to meet you. Would that be alright?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John, I'd like you to meet one of the brightest lights of the British stage, Mrs. Kendal. Mrs. Kendal, John Merrick.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Good day, Mr. Merrick.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Good day...!

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: I've brought you some things. I hope you'll like, Mr. Merrick. I hope you don't think it too forward.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh, no.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: I knew you'd understand. Here.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: I want you to know that I don't go about giving my pictures to just anyone.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh, no. I would never think it! It's so beautiful. You are so... I'll give it a place of honor, here, next to my mother.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: She's very pretty, your mother.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Mr. Treves says that you are in the theatre. Do you live there?

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. I just work there.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Well, even to work there would be wonderful. Is it beautiful?

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: You've never been?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Alas, no.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Well you must go. It is one of the most beautiful places on earth. Of course, I'm rather partial.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Tell me about it, please!

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: It's very difficult to put into a nutshell, but I should say the theater is the shrine of the imagination, where one may suspend disbelief and travel anywhere in the world, to any time you desire. You may look over the shoulders of kings, unobserved, battle with ruthless tyrants, and marry the beautiful princess, all in the space of a few hours. Onstage you may be whoever you wish to be, do anything you please, and always, always live happily ever after. The theatre is all the brightest and best things of the world, Mr. Merrick. It is lights and music, gaiety and joy. It's... well, it's romance.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Romance!

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: That's one thing the theatre has in great store. which reminds me. I have something else for you...

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Have you read it?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: No, but I certainly shall.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Romeo and Juliet. I know of this... "If I profane with my unworthiest hand, This holy shrine, the gentle fine is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand, To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss."

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmer's kiss.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do. They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Why, Mr. Merrick, you're not an Elephant Man at all...

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh no?

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Oh no... no... you're a Romeo.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: So, there you are, my boy, my treasure.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Mummy, listen to this!

Speaker: mummy
Dialogue: Hush, Jennifer, can't you see Mummy's talking?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: But it's about Mrs. Kendal, mummy! The actress you go on so much about!

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: "Mrs. Kendal, always at the forefront of fashion and form, was seen leaving The London the other afternoon. No, dear readers, the most facile actress of our day has not been taken ill, but rather said she was 'visiting a friend'. And who was the lucky recipient of this attention? Quick enquiries proved it to be none other than Mr. John Merrick, The Elephant Man, with whom our readers are undoubtedly familiar. After a chat of three-quarters of an hour, Mrs. Kendal was kind enough to leave Mr. Merrick with an autographed portrait of herself. Owing to a disfigurement of the most extreme nature, Mr. Merrick has never been properly presented to London society. But knowing that wherever Mrs. Kendal goes, others inevitably follow, the questions arises: Will London society present itself to him?"

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Parkins, whose carriage is that?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Well mum, that looks like Alexander, Lord Waddington's driver.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Lord and Lady Waddington! Well. Drive back to the house.  I can't be seen in this.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Thank you for your kind gifts. I can't say enough about this ring. And this walking stick is ever so dashing. So much more elegant than my old one. More tea?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: If you have a chill I can close the window.

Speaker: the lady
Dialogue: Oh no, no, no, I'm fine. Please... I mean, thank you.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I don't get out as often as I'd like to, for some people DO find my appearance disturbing. Of course, I can't fault them.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Watery headed bunch.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I regret that I must leave you here, m' Lord, m' Lady. Thank you so much for coming. It was an act of the greatest charity.

Speaker: lady waddington
Dialogue: Oh no, Mr. Treves, the pleasure was all ours. Good day.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Incredible, isn't it? Well, I think John has had enough visitors for one day, Mothershead. I've got a lecture at the college, I'll be back this evening.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir. I'd like to have a word with you.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Oh?... Well, quickly please, Mothershead, I'm overdue.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: I can't understand why you let those people go in there, sir.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Now Mothershead, you have to understand that this is very good for John. He relishes contact with people outside the hospital...

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: But you saw them, sir. They couldn't hide their disgust. They don't care anything for John, they're just trying to impress their friends.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Aren't you being just a little harsh, Mothershead? You yourself hardly treated John with much loving kindness when he first arrived.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: I bathed him, didn't I? I fed him and cleaned up after him! If loving kindness can be called care and practical concern, then yes, I did treat him with loving kindness, and I'm not ashamed to say it.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: You're right, Mothershead, please forgive me... Of course, I appreciate everything you've done for John, and I'm glad that you are concerned about his welfare. But, I'm the physician in charge and I must do what I think best. I'm also very late, so please forgive me.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: If you ask me, sir, he's just being stared at all over again.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: When will the stream be aweary of flowing under my eye? When will the wind be aweary of blowing over the sky? When will the clouds be aweary of fleeting? When will the heart be aweary of beating, and nature die?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Never, oh! Never, nothing will die. the stream flows the wind blows the heart beats Nothing will die.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Mr. Treves, there is something I've been meaning to ask you for some time...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, John?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: ...Can you cure me?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: No John, I can't. I can care for you, but I can't cure you.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I thought as much.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John...?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Are you looking for me, Sister?

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: No sir, Mr. Merrick.  I have something for you.

Speaker: nora
Dialogue: I thought these things would be helpful with your cathedral.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: The cathedral is coming along nicely.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yes, soon I will start the main spire, but I must finish these columns first, How kind of her!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: How blind of me. Is there anything else, John, anything at all that I could get for you?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh no! There is nothing! I have everything, you have given me everything I could possibly want. I am happy every hour of the day. I only wish there was something I could give to you.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Please John, it would give me so much pleasure to give you something. Something just for yourself. Isn't there something you would like to have?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: You want a dressing bag, John?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: You don't think it's too gaudy, do you?

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Mr. Treves, some more books arrived for Mr. Merrick.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Thank you, Mothershead. Have a porter put them in my office.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Yes sir.  What's that?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: A dressing bag.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Very smart indeed.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes. John wants it.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: A dressing bag?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: You don't think it's too gaudy, do you.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John thinks it's very dashing. Something no gentleman should be without. I'm inclined to agree.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: A dressing bag?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Night!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: You stay with me.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Dinner will be served, shortly, dear.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: More romances for John?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Hmmm?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: ...Freddie! What's the matter? You've been like this all evening.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Oh... I've just been thinking about something that man Bytes said.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh, Freddie. What could that wretched vampire say to upset you?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: That I am very little different from him.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh that's absurd, Frederick. No, no Frederick, that's all wrong! John is happier and more fulfilled now than he has ever been in his entire life. And, that is completely due to you.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: But why did I do it? What was this all for? So John Merrick could live out his last days in peace and comfort? Or so I could become famous?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Frederick, just what is it that you are saying?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: ...Am I a good man or am I a bad man?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh Frederick.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: You're a good man. A very good man.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Ahh! Broadneck! You'll no doubt be pleased to know that we've received a smashing response to my letter. It's all very heartwarming, though several letters do mention how beastly it would be to part the poor fellow from Mr. Treves and the staff, but since the committee insists...

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: Good day, Carr Gomm.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Is this all there is for John?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: I'm afraid so, Mrs. Mothershead. Perhaps tomorrow.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: What is it? What is it?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Don't you think this is a bit premature? We don't have the backing yet to...

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Steady on, Treves. Have a seat.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I know we begin every meeting by reading the minutes, but in the interest of speed I think we should conclude a matter discussed previously, to wit, that of Mr. John Merrick, the Elephant Man...

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Mr. Broadneck?

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: Mr. Chairman! I was under the distinct impression that we had concluded discussion of this disagreeable matter. Had we not ascertained that an Elephant Man is not acceptable as a patient? Have we not, very generously, allowed the creature to use two of our rooms until such time as he could be properly disposed of? Have we not...

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I must be more careful!

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: Which brings to mind my next point. The rules, gentlemen, the rules. In a society such as ours, it is of paramount importance that we not stray from the established order. Has that order not already been fearfully strained by allowing this... this... sideshow exhibit to take up residence, however temporary, in two very useful rooms, the purpose of which would be far better served in accommodating treatable patients, patients to whom this hospital was originally dedicated? I believe we have a duty...

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: ...Ladybug, ladybug, fly away home... it's cloudy out, I know, but remember; behind the clouds there is always the sun.

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: ...In light of these facts, our course is clear. The question is not whether to accept this creature as a patient, the question is when will those rooms be vacated for use by better qualified, more deserving cases? I move that this Elephant Man be removed from the premises immediately. We have a sacred duty to cure the sick, not care for circus animals. That is my last word on the subject. Mr. Chairman, shall we vote?

Speaker: carr gomm
Dialogue: I take it, Mr. Broadneck, that your mind is fixed on this matter?

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: Mr. Chairman! Don't you have ears? I am unalterably opposed to any...

Speaker: broadneck
Dialogue: ...No, my mind is made up on this, and I am resolved to stand firm. You shall not sway me. May we now vote, Mr. Chairman, at long last?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Yes, I believe that time has come.

Speaker: alix
Dialogue: Good morning, gentlemen. I hope I am not interrupting?

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Indeed not, your Highness. Your presence is always greatly appreciated. We were just about to put the matter of Mr. Merrick to a vote.  The Princess is very interested in Mr. Merrick's fate.

Speaker: alix
Dialogue: Indeed I am sir, as is the Queen. I have a brief communication from her Highness which she has requested I read to you: To the Governing Committee, London Hospital. I would very much like to commend you for the charitable face you have shown Mr. John Merrick, the Elephant Man. It is laudable that you have provided one of England's most unfortunate sons with a safe and tranquil harbour, a home. For this immeasurable kindness, as well as the many other acts of mercy on behalf of the poor, of which Mr. Carr Gomm has kept me informed, I gratefully thank you. Signed Victoria, Empress of India, Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.  I am sure you gentlemen may be counted on to do the Christian thing.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Thank you very much, your Highness, you may be sure we shall.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Well then, I move that Mr. John Merrick be admitted to the London Hospital on a permanent basis, on condition that the Hospital shall receive a yearly payment equal to the cost of occupying one bed, and that the funds for his care shall be clearly separate from hospital funds. All those in favor.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: The motion is carried.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Well, now we may go about our normal business.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Please, come in.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Good afternoon, John, Mr. Carr Gomm has something he would like to say to you.

Speaker: carr
Dialogue: Mr. Merrick, it is my great pleasure to welcome you, officially to The London Hospital. The Governing Committee this morning voted unanimously to provide you these rooms on a permanent basis. This is your home now. I'm so very, very pleased for you.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: So you see, John, there's no need for a lighthouse. All your friends are here.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Welcome home, John.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: ...my... home?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, John.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: You did this for me?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Please... please thank the governing committee for me. I will do my utmost to merit their kindness.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: My home.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: There is one more thing, John. Here.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Is it the one you wanted?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Treves. Mr. Treves.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Are you sure? Because I can take it back.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Mr. Treves. Thank you my... friends.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Here now, these lovely ladies ain't never seen it!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Alright, alright, that's enough for this performance.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Hang on, hang on, there's always tomorrow night. Not to worry.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Room for one more?

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: At the right price...

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: There's room.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Well, let's be off then.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Quietly now! Quietly! We don't want to scare him.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Hello, my name is John Merrick. I am very, VERY pleased to meet you!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Curtain time!!!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: No, no! You look lovely. Don't change a thing, darling. You look like the bleedin' Prince of Wales.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: My friends... The Elephant Man!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Perhaps the ladies would like a closer look?

Speaker: whores
Dialogue: Come on Jack... No... No, don't.  Etc.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: 'Cor, he's a real ladies' man, come on... give the ladies' man a kiss.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Come on, you'll give him a kiss.

Speaker: whore
Dialogue: Come on, Jack.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Here that's enough romance. Now into bed.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: A prince needs a harem!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Mind his head... You'll kill him.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Quiet down. Quiet down. You'll have the whole place down on us.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Bring him out then, so's we all can see him.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Everyone outside!!!

Speaker: one man
Dialogue: Give 'im a drink.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Meet you at the Peacock.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: He's had 'is fill for one night.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: I did real well tonight.

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Here... buy yourself a sweet.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Aren't you glad to see me?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Bytes!

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John?

Speaker: young porter
Dialogue: Mr. Treves?

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Good God... John?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: WHERE IS HE?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: WHERE IS MR. MERRICK?

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: I... I don't know what you mean, Sir.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Don't lie to me. I know all about it. You were SEEN. Where did you take him?

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Take him? Now wait... I didn't take him anywhere. We were just having some fun. We didn't hurt him... just having a laugh, that's all.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: HE'S GONE!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: When I left him, he was in his bed, safe and sound.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: YOU BASTARD! You tortured him. YOU TORTURED HIM, you bastard. WHERE is HE?

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: YOU'RE NOT LISTENING TO ME! I ain't done nothing wrong. People pay to see your monster, Mr. Treves. I just take the money.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: YOU'RE THE MONSTER! YOU'RE THE FREAK! GET OUT! YOU'RE FINISHED!

Speaker: night porter
Dialogue: Have a care, Mr. Treves. I ain't afraid of you! You and your bleedin' Elephant Man! I'm glad what I did! And you can't do nothing! Only Mothershead can sack me.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: Done.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Still haven't eaten, eh?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Bytes... please!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Eat, my treasure, I want you healthy.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: I'm beginning to feel your weight.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: ...The result is plain to see. Ladies and Gentlemen... THE TERRIBLE ELEPHANT MAN!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Turn around!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Dance!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Dance!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Eat, my treasure.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Eat. I said eat!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Eat, damn you. EAT! EAT!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: I said EAT!!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: The result is plain to see. Ladies and gentlemen... THE TERRIBLE ELEPHANT MAN.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Turn around!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Dance!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Up! Up!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Give the call of the elephant!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Louder!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Get up you miserable bastard!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: I SAID, GET UP!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: I'm beatin' a dead horse.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Another bleedin' heart!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: You sly bastard. You're doing this to spite me, aren't you!

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Aw, Bytes, he's sick.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: He's doing it to spite me, I tell you, and it's got to stop!

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: He's sick, Bytes. He's going to die.

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: If he does it's his own fault! But I'm not burying that swollen bag of flesh.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: What are you going to do?

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: I'll show you! I'll show you!

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Don't!

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Bytes, please...

Speaker: bytes
Dialogue: Out!

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Bytes! Bytes, please!!

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: NO! I AM NOT AN ELEPHANT! I AM NOT AN ANIMAL!! I AM A HUMAN BEING! I... AM... A MAN! I AM A MAN!!

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: You alright?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: y-y-yes--

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: Want to come out?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: You're English.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: Of course! You want out?

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: Won't be a moment.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: We've decided... You've got to get away from here...

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Here... you'll need these.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: Good of you, mate.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Good luck.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: But... but...

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: I'll be alright.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Thank you, my friends.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: I'll go in with you, you'll need a ticket.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: I'm just going to help my friend on board.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: This'll do.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: I'm sorry I could only get you a third class ticket, but it's all we had.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh no, my friend...

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: Say hello to London for me. I miss her.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: You know, I saw you once there, in London. You're a great attraction.

Speaker: plumed dwarf
Dialogue: Luck, my friend, luck. Who needs it more than we?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: I'm sorry, you'll have to leave now.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: This is the end of the line, you'll have to leave now.

Speaker: ticket taker
Dialogue: Wait! One more!

Speaker: ticket taker
Dialogue: You'll have to hurr...

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: Finally! Dover!

Speaker: mother's voice
Dialogue: Little beast! I thought mummy told you not to bring that horrid thing. Can't you behave?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Mummy! Mummy! Look at that man! His head, it's huge! Mummy, why is his head so big? Mummy? Mummy?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Do be quiet Little Jim. Can't you see Mummy is speaking?

Speaker: little jim
Dialogue: Hey Mister, why is your head so big?

Speaker: little jim
Dialogue: Mister!

Speaker: boys
Dialogue: Mister! Mister!

Speaker: little jim
Dialogue: Why don't you answer me?

Speaker: little jim
Dialogue: Now I'll see you...

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: My son! My son! Help!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Stop that man! Stop that man!

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I am not an animal... I'm not... I'm not... I am a man.

Speaker: mothershead
Dialogue: There's a policeman to see you, Sir.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Are you Frederick Treves, sir?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes...

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: You know this man, sir?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes, he's... my friend.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Mr. Treves! Treves.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: John.... how can you ever forgive me?

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: It's all arranged. I'll send over some evening gowns for the sisters that you select to accompany Mr. Merrick. You'll be using the Royal entrance and Princess Alexandra herself will be there to welcome him to her private box.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I'm very grateful to you, Mrs. Kendal. This is just the thing to help him forget his ordeal. John will be very excited.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Well it is a miracle he ever got back. And, I'm sure, Mr. Treves, under your expert care, he'll have many happy years ahead.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: I fear not, Mrs. Kendal. Even in the short time he was gone the size of his head has increased rapidly... as is his pain.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: How awful for John.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: And yet, not once have any of us heard him complain.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Is he... dying then?

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes. There is nothing more frustrating, nothing that makes a physician feel more useless, than standing by watching his patient deteriorate. And when that patient is a friend, no... no, there's absolutely nothing I can do.

Speaker: kendal
Dialogue: Well, it's all quite... I've never heard... It's quite...

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: You women are such strange and wonderful creatures... Alas, it seems to be my fate to fall in love with each and everyone of you. I especially wish you could all be with me tonight... I'm finally going to the theatre.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: ...The theatre...

Speaker: chorus
Dialogue: O for a Muse of fire, that would ascend The brightest heaven of invention, A kingdom for a stage, princes to act And monarchs to behold the swelling scene! Then should the warlike Harry, like himself, Assume the port of Mars; and at his heels, Leash'd in like hounds, should famine, sword and fire Crouch for employment. But pardon, gentles all, The flat unraised spirits that have dar'd On this unworthy scaffold to bring forth So great an object: can this cockpit hold The vasty fields of Rance? Or may we cram Within this wooden O the very casques That did affright the air at Agincourt? O, pardon! since a crooked figure may Attest in little place a million; And let us, ciphers to this great account, On your imaginary forces work.

Speaker: kath
Dialogue: Your majesty shall mock at me; I cannot speak your England.

Speaker: kath
Dialogue: Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell vat is "like me".

Speaker: kath
Dialogue: O bon Dieu! les langues des hommes sont pleines de tramperies.

Speaker: kath
Dialogue: Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits.

Speaker: chorus
Dialogue: Thus far, with rough and allunable pen, Our bending author hath pursued the story, In little room confining mighty men, Mangling by starts the full course of their glory. Small time, but in that small most greatly liv'd This star of England: Fortune made his sword; By which the world's best garden he achiev'd.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Stand up, John. Let them see you.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Oh no, I couldn't.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: It's for you, John. It's all for you. Go ahead, let them see you.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: I feel as if I've traveled my whole life just to stand here.

Speaker: merrick
Dialogue: Wasn't Mrs. Kendal wonderful? I can't blame the King for wanting to marry her.

Speaker: treves
Dialogue: Will the cathedral be finished soon, John?

Speaker: merrick
